result.markdown:
---
title: "Class10 Structural Bioinformatics Pt1 (11/01/24)"
author: "Janie Chang-Weinberg (A69037446)"
format: pdf
---



What is in the PDB database anyway?
Summary data grabbed from:
https://www.rcsb.org/stats/summary



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
pdbstats <- read.csv("PDB_stats_summaryfile.csv", row.names = 1)
pdbstats
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
                          X.ray     EM    NMR Multiple.methods Neutron Other
Protein (only)          167,317 15,698 12,534              208      77    32
Protein/Oligosaccharide   9,645  2,639     34                8       2     0
Protein/NA                8,735  4,718    286                7       0     0
Nucleic acid (only)       2,869    138  1,507               14       3     1
Other                       170     10     33                0       0     0
Oligosaccharide (only)       11      0      6                1       0     4
                          Total
Protein (only)          195,866
Protein/Oligosaccharide  12,328
Protein/NA               13,746
Nucleic acid (only)       4,532
Other                       213
Oligosaccharide (only)       22
```


:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
x <- pdbstats$Total
x
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] "195,866" "12,328"  "13,746"  "4,532"   "213"     "22"     
```


:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
#as.numeric(x): Warning: NAs introduced by coercion[1]  NA  NA  NA  NA 213  22
```
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
gsub(',', '', x)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] "195866" "12328"  "13746"  "4532"   "213"    "22"    
```


:::
:::



doesn't like the commas, ask google. can also use "claude" 
use gsub to replace commas with nothings


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
convertednocomma <- function(x){
  #remove comma
  x <- gsub(',', '', x)
  #convert to numeric
  x <- as.numeric(x)
  return(x)
}
```
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
convertednocomma(pdbstats$Total)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] 195866  12328  13746   4532    213     22
```


:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
n.tot <- sum(convertednocomma(pdbstats$Total))
n.tot
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] 226707
```


:::
:::



The `apply()` function is very useful as it can take any function and "Apply" it over either the ROWS or COLs of a data.frame.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
colSums(apply(pdbstats, 2, convertednocomma))/n.tot
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
           X.ray               EM              NMR Multiple.methods 
    0.8325592064     0.1023479646     0.0635181093     0.0010498132 
         Neutron            Other            Total 
    0.0003617003     0.0001632063     1.0000000000 
```


:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
#another way of importing data to avoid issues with commas in the numbas
#library(readr)
#read_csv("PDB_stats_summaryfile.csv")
```
:::



Q1: What percentage of structures in the PDB are solved by X-Ray and Electron Microscopy?



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
n.xray <- sum(convertednocomma(pdbstats$X.ray))
n.em <- sum(convertednocomma(pdbstats$EM))

xraypercent <- ((n.xray/n.tot)*100)
empercent <- ((n.em/n.tot)*100)

xraypercent
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] 83.25592
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
empercent
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] 10.2348
```


:::
:::


>83.26% (xray%), 10.23% (EM%)

Q2. What proportion of structures in the PDB are protein?



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
n.totalprots <- 195866/n.tot

n.totalprots
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] 0.863961
```


:::
:::


> 86.4%

Q3: Type HIV in the PDB website search box on the home page and determine how many HIV-1 protease structures are in the current PDB?

> 4,640

## Using Mol*

![My first image from Mol-star :D](1HSG.png)

Q4: Water molecules normally have 3 atoms. Why do we see just one atom per water molecule in this structure?

>Cannot see Hydrogen at this resolution, the only atom being displayed here is oxygen. 

Q5: There is a critical “conserved” water molecule in the binding site. Can you identify this water molecule? What residue number does this water molecule have

> This water molecule's residue number is HOH 308

Q6: Generate and save a figure clearly showing the two distinct chains of HIV-protease along with the ligand. You might also consider showing the catalytic residues ASP 25 in each chain and the critical water (we recommend “Ball & Stick” for these side-chains). Add this figure to your Quarto document.

>![with Aspartate residues and H2O mol](1HSG_withwater.png)

## Use the Bio3D package for structural Bioinformatics



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
library(bio3d)

pdb <- read.pdb("1hsg")
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
  Note: Accessing on-line PDB file
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
pdb
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```

 Call:  read.pdb(file = "1hsg")

     Total Atoms#: 1686,  XYZs#: 5058  Chains#: 2  (values: A B)

     Protein Atoms#: 1514  (residues/Calpha atoms#: 198)
     Nucleic acid Atoms#: 0  (residues/phosphate atoms#: 0)

     Non-protein/nucleic Atoms#: 172  (residues: 128)
```

```{.r .cell-code}

```

```
 25 
"D" 
```

Q7. How many amino acids are there in this structure?


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
length(pdbseq(pdb))
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] 198
```


:::
:::


> There are 198 amino acids in this structure

Q8. Name one of the two non-protein residues?

> HOH (water)

Q9. How many protein chains are in this structure?

> 2



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
adk <- read.pdb("6s36")
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
  Note: Accessing on-line PDB file
   PDB has ALT records, taking A only, rm.alt=TRUE
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
adk
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```

 Call:  read.pdb(file = "6s36")
```

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
library(r3dmol)
source("https://tinyurl.com/viewpdb")

library(shiny)
view.pdb(pdb)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](JCW_110124_bioinfo_Class10_files/figure-pdf/unnamed-chunk-18-1.pdf){fig-pos='H'}
:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
modes <- nma(adk)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
 Building Hessian...		Done in 0.018 seconds.
 Diagonalizing Hessian...	Done in 0.342 seconds.
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
plot(modes)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](JCW_110124_bioinfo_Class10_files/figure-pdf/unnamed-chunk-19-1.pdf){fig-pos='H'}
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
mktrj(modes, pdb=adk, file='adk.pdb') #give it the pdb= thing to have proper seq
```
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
mktrj(modes, file="adk_m7.pdb")
```
:::




Q10. Which of the packages above is found only on BioConductor and not CRAN?

> biocmanager

Q.11 Which of the above packages is not found on BioConductor or CRAN?

> bio3d 

Q.12 True or False? Functions from the devtools package can be used to install packages from GitHub and BitBucket?

> True





::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
library(bio3d)
aa <- get.seq("1ake_A")
```

Q13. How many amino acids are in this sequence, i.e. how long is this sequence?

> There are 214 AAs

##Blast or hmmer search 


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
b <- blast.pdb(aa)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
 Searching ... please wait (updates every 5 seconds) RID = JP0JPEGF016 
 .................
 Reporting 85 hits
```


:::
:::



##Plot a summary of search results:


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
hits <- plot(b)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
  * Possible cutoff values:    197 11 
            Yielding Nhits:    19 85 

  * Chosen cutoff value of:    197 
            Yielding Nhits:    19 
```


:::

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](JCW_110124_bioinfo_Class10_files/figure-pdf/unnamed-chunk-23-1.pdf){fig-pos='H'}
:::
:::



##List some "Top Hits" and download their .pdb files:


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
head(hits$pdb.id)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] "1AKE_A" "8BQF_A" "4X8M_A" "6S36_A" "8Q2B_A" "8RJ9_A"
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
files <- get.pdb(hits$pdb.id, path="pdbs", split=TRUE, gzip=TRUE)
```

##Align and Superimpose structures:


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
pdbs <- pdbaln(files, fit = TRUE, exefile="msa")
```

##Annotate PDB Structures


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
anno <- pdb.annotate(ids)
unique(anno$source)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}


##Perform PCA


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
pc.xray <- pca(pdbs)
plot(pc.xray)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](JCW_110124_bioinfo_Class10_files/figure-pdf/unnamed-chunk-29-1.pdf){fig-pos='H'}
:::
:::


##Calculate RMSD and show structure-based clustering


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
rd <- rmsd(pdbs)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}

```
Warning in rmsd(pdbs): No indices provided, using the 199 non NA positions
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
hc.rd <- hclust(dist(rd))
grps.rd <- cutree(hc.rd, k=3)

plot(pc.xray, 1:2, col="grey50", bg=grps.rd, pch=21, cex=1)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](JCW_110124_bioinfo_Class10_files/figure-pdf/unnamed-chunk-30-1.pdf){fig-pos='H'}
:::
:::
